question: How long does a complete rotation of the Moon on its axis take?

content.source_1: The Moon completes one full 360-degree orbit around Earth relative to the distant stars (a sidereal month) in about 27.3 days.
content.source_2: The Moon is tidally locked to Earth, so it turns once on its axis during each orbit, keeping nearly the same hemisphere facing Earth.
content.source_3: From Earth’s surface, the far side of the Moon is never directly visible; observers always see the same hemisphere.
content.source_4: Over a month of naked-eye viewing, the Moon’s face does not appear to spin; prominent maria and craters keep an essentially fixed orientation on the visible disk.
content.source_5: Lunar libration slightly “rocks” the Moon’s apparent face, allowing Earth-based observers to see about 59% of the surface over time, but never the far side all at once.
content.source_6: Spacecraft imagery has photographed the Moon’s far side—never seen directly from Earth—confirming that the hemisphere facing Earth remains essentially the same throughout its orbit.
